unnormalised: Delhi Discoms Report Peak Summer Usage, Twitter Erupts in Memes!
normalised: Delhi Discoms Report Peak Summer Usage, Twitter Erupts in Memes!

unnormalised: The summer heatwave has sent Delhi’s electricity consumption soaring, with discoms reporting peak demand touching a record 7,695 MW at 3:22 PM yesterday. This is about 12% higher than last year's peak, and frankly, my AC bill is already making me weep! Sources say that the increased usage is primarily due to households running ACs and coolers non-stop. One resident, Mr. Sharma from Dwarka, reported his bill jumped from Rs. 3500 in May to a whopping Rs. 7850 this June! "At this rate, I might as well sell my kidney to pay the electricity bill," he joked... mostly.
normalised: The summer heatwave has sent Delhi’s electricity consumption soaring, with discoms reporting peak demand touching a record seven thousand six hundred and ninety five M-W at three twenty two P-M yesterday. This is about twelve percent higher than last year's peak, and frankly, my A-C bill is already making me weep! Sources say that the increased usage is primarily due to households running A-Cs and coolers non-stop. One resident, Mister Sharma from Dwarka, reported his bill jumped from rupees three thousand five hundred in May to a whopping rupees seven thousand eight hundred and fifty this June! "At this rate, I might as well sell my kidney to pay the electricity bill," he joked... mostly.

unnormalised: Naturally, social media is ablaze. #DelhiHeat #ElectricityBill and #PowerCut have been trending all day. One user quipped, "My electricity meter is spinning faster than a Bollywood dance number!" Another meme shows a person dramatically clutching their chest with the caption: "Me checking my electricity bill after running the AC at 16°C." Several users have complained about voltage fluctuations and unscheduled power cuts in areas like Rohini and Janakpuri. Apparently, the discom helpline number 1912 is receiving more calls than a chai stall on a rainy day.

unnormalised: Adding to the humor (or horror, depending on your bill size), many are sharing tips to save electricity. "Switch off lights when not in use" is being followed by "but who can live without AC in this Garmi?!". The debate rages on. Energy experts are advising households to switch to energy-efficient appliances, like those with a 5-star BEE rating, and consider solar panels if they want to retire before they're 80. One suggested only using fans which cost a mere Rs. 50 to operate for 8 hours. Right, because that will cut it at 46°C.

unnormalised: Meanwhile, discom officials are assuring residents that they are prepared to meet the increased demand. They’ve apparently invested Rs. 200 crore in infrastructure upgrades. Now, if only they could invent a way to make the sun less… sun-y. Till then, keep calm, drink nimbu pani, and brace yourselves, because your next electricity bill might just be the plot twist in your otherwise uneventful life. God save us all.
